nodes.text: i think that in many, if not most of these cases of police brutality, the officers are probably genuinely frightened, leading to rash decisions.\nthe problem is that this fear-induced hysteria is unbefitting of a professional of any kind, much less those meant to keep the peace --

@the1janitor I think that it is very important to empathetically understand people and their motives to understand social phenomenon. Otherwise we might tend to demonize people we would call „problematic“ or „dangerous“ but most likely blur the opportunity to really understand something.

@the1janitor 100%, and it’s made worse by a country with more guns than people. Most countries with less police violence don’t have to deal with the genuine possibility that somebody could shoot back. Not an excuse for murder, but a factor worth remembering.
@SkullBearer @the1janitor Your trainer's the best, I hope he knows that

@DenmanLev @the1janitor I mean, he was good, but I think that's just the basics for self defence. You need to overcome the flight/fight/freeze response to be able to act rationally in an emergency. If someone has pulled a knife or a gun on you, running in to punch him will end tragically.

@amnevitah @NightwingPhD @the1janitor I've seen ppl say that, then refer to videos and such of interactions where police were shot as a "This is what could happen to you at any time" warning, as though cops need to engage with every situation like it is an extreme one
@BrigidStakelum @the1janitor And some of the worst gun crime in the developed world
@AllBeefedUp @the1janitor I know, thats why I specified that some cops could still have guns. However, I do still believe that cop training relies too heavily on guns instead of conflict resolution.
@BrigidStakelum @the1janitor Might work if your country dident have more guns than people

@the1janitor And if they get scared that often, why do they have guns in the first place? Now I'm not saying that no cops should have guns, but how many lives would be saved if we reduced the amount of guns cops had and focused more on peaceful conflict resolution?
The issue is that this "fear" seems to be enough to convince juries, judges, and much of the public that killing black people in these situations is somehow lawful

@the1janitor a v strange form of fear too, escalating conflict with black people over small infractions, random inanities or literally for no reason, & somehow judging those unthreatening inciting events as hugely dangerous — these are people so distorted they should literally wield no power

@the1janitor They’re trained to be terrified and to consider themselves entirely separate from “civilians” in a permanent siege mentality. And any criticism they get just reinforces for them that the public is the enemy. They do not serve the people, they are in antagonism to most of us
@the1janitor There are countless videos where they deliberately escalate things though, you are giving them a HUGE and undue benefit of the doubt
@the1janitor and who carry guns
@the1janitor It’s weird that cops are given a free pass for freaking out in tense situations while civilians with no training are expected to keep a cool head.
@WrathItchy @the1janitor Play Simon Says or die citizen!

@the1janitor It kinda weirds me out because that kind of fear response was what my krav maga trainer worked so hard to drill out of us, and we were just a bunch of randos who wanted to do a self defence course.
@the1janitor That might be the case but I thought they were supposed to be trained to deal with stressful situations with calm responses? Either they ignored training or they aren't trained properly
and this fear is almost certainly very frequently based on an irrational perception of black men as more threatening than they actually are

@the1janitor the fear is less irrational than based on falae premises. They are trained and indoctrinated to be this way. They are made to think this worldview is correct. From their perspective it makes perfect sense.\n\nthe problem is why they are taught this way.

@the1janitor This fear might also be rational: they may actually know that the black person they need to arrest is genuinely afraid for their life because of past police actions, therefore may panic violently. Hence cops feel they need to brace for confrontation. Talk about a vicious circle.
@melainekerfaou @the1janitor no.
@the1janitor I mean it makes sense. Half of police training is them watching videos of people getting shot during traffic stops apparently. This irrational level of fear is a feature, not a bug.
@the1janitor Why is the fear of black men rightfully scared for their lives never a justification for them not complying?
@the1janitor "fear for one's life" needs to be removed as an excuse for cop shootings. Because shooting someone is not the only remendy when one fears for their life.

@the1janitor yep, the "fear" defense maybe more acurate to "reality", but is really worse... becouse now we are talking not only of a "bad apple", but a complete failure of a sistem. They are basica acepting criminal negligence.

@theDwarf @the1janitor Well that is the problem though. The ones in charge of training/leadership often ARE the bad ones, teaching the new officers. It is a systemic failure. Bad apples spoil the bunch. To fix it, you have to cut out the bad ones but also intentionally attack the rot they created.

@the1janitor Just one example but replicable studies show people perceive Black men to be much taller, stronger than they are, moreso than any other racial group, as well as dangerous. The stereotyping and warped, violent portrayals of Black men has to stop.

@the1janitor Another issue isn't just the fear, but also the reactiom afterwards. Less people would be upset if police forces dealt with situations quickly and honestly and brought some consequence for the police officer involved instead of protecting them from even the slightest punishment.
@the1janitor We have essentially given scared children guns and told them to do what they think is right.
@the1janitor Tbh this fear would be a lot harder to justify if not every schmoe could carry a gun.
@the1janitor One of the best takes on Twitter, @the1janitor   Truly.

@the1janitor Mhm, and "fear" is never enough to justify non-compliance and/or running by Black people (or those with mental illness). /Their/ fear is so often seen as justification for the cops' fear, as if being afraid of being shot is a proxy for guilt.

@the1janitor @the1janitor You're right, and you need to look up the supreme court case Kisela v Hughes. Because it proves you're right, and that it's functionally impossible to prosecute a uniformed, on-duty police officer for wrongful death.
@the1janitor Racist cops + racist juries = a match made in hell
@the1janitor plus a lot of them consume media that constantly tells them that theyre in more danger than they actually are
